title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watersheds, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region for the protection of watersheds, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values. The Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994 authorizes appropriations for acquiring land described in section 2 and allows for the transfer of funds to the Commission to carry out the Act. This Act may be cited as the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994". The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. Sterling Forest, a biologically diverse area on the New Jersey border, is a significant watershed covering approximately 17,500 acres. Over 8 million visitors annually enjoy outdoor recreational opportunities within the Palisades Park System. Sterling Forest is a biologically diverse open space on the New Jersey border, covering 17,500 acres. It is a significant watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of New Jersey. The forest supports a variety of habitats and is home to 27 rare or endangered species, enhancing the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. Sterling Forest, covering 17,500 acres on the New Jersey border, is a significant watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of New Jersey. It supports 27 rare or endangered species, enhancing the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and offering recreational opportunities. The protection of Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship by New York and New Jersey. The Palisades Interstate Park Commission aims to acquire Sterling Forest for permanent protection of its watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities, as well as open space. This is seen as a cost-effective investment compared to the expenses of protecting the region's drinking water if the forest is developed. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York aims to protect watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources in the region. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and management will be overseen by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" means the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE STERLING FOREST RESERVE. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established by the Commission upon acquiring sufficient lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition. The Secretary will transfer funds to the Commission for the acquisition of lands within the Sterling Forest Reserve. The Commission must agree to specific terms and conditions before receiving federal funds, including managing the acquired lands in accordance with the Act and conveying fee title to the United States if not compliant. No federal funds can be used to acquire lands without following the conditions outlined. The Commission must agree to specific terms and conditions before receiving federal funds for acquiring lands within the Sterling Forest Reserve. Federal funds can only be used with the owner's consent, and if all lands cannot be acquired, priority should be given to acquiring National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands. The Commission must convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands within 30 days of acquisition. The easements are to ensure the lands are managed to protect their wilderness character. The Commission must convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands to protect their wilderness character. Funds for the Commission must be matched from non-Federal sources. The Commission will manage lands in the Reserve in line with its authorities and the Act's purposes. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years for approval. Appropriations are authorized for Act implementation, with a limit of $17,500,000 for land acquisition within the Reserve.
